bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton, February 15, 1724

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Liverpool merchant John Pemberton, February 15, 1724, to complain about the last shipment of slave shoes from him which the shoemaker--"a rank cheat "-- had marked as larger than they were. He orders replacement shoes to be "the best Strong plain Carmens Shoos that You can buy for Money."

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton, February 15, 1724

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Feb. 15th. 1723/4
Mr. Jno. Pemberton

div1.p:
Since the Sailing of Fowler, I have overhauld the
Shoos You sent me last Year, they prove Very ordinary the Shoomaker
hath bin a rank cheat & hath markd many of the Shoos at high sizes
When the biggest of them do not Exceed the 12s. I shall be at a mighty loss
to fitt my largest people, The Shoos You sent me the Year before
were very good & answerd their Sizes very well, I am doubtfull
Your next which I Expect are coming will be of the same Stamp wth.
these last, therefore for fear of the worst I desire You will take the
[firs]t Opportunity You have, to send me in Six doz. of the best Strong
plain Carmens Shoos that You can buy for Money, one half of them
to be of the large 16s. the other of the 14s. You must not stick at price
And I would also have two doz. of large mens French Falls and
two doz. of Woms., I am in hopes I may get these Shoos by next Fall
or at farthest Early in the Winter, I would beg Yor. Sons particular
care in the buying these Shoos, that I may be well servd according to
my desire,

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1723 July 4 -1724 June 11, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.
[1] Captain William Keiling commanded the Betty. (Survey Report 6800, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia)
